Introduction

Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) has risen alarmingly over the lastyears, there has been a 32% increase in the estimated number of antibiotic resistant bloodstream infections from key bacterial species between 2015 and 2019; overprescribing, prolonged and inappropriate use of antimicrobials are the main drivers. Antibiotic consumption in England has been falling since the peak in 2014, but the use in hospitals (by hospital admissions) has increased by 3.5% over the last 5years.

The consequences of AMR which include treatment failure, and limited antimicrobial choices have led to the issue of Patient Safety Alert (August 2015), by both NHS England and Public Health England (PHE).
This alert aims to highlight the importance of antimicrobial stewardship through the development of Start Smart-Then Focus antimicrobial stewardship toolkit.

Significant concerns regarding overprescribing have also led to the development of AMR CQUIN in April 2016, and nationwide Antibiotic Guardian (AG) campaign. AG campaign website was visited 82,992 times in 2019, which resulted in 9,289 pledges.

The Health & Social Care Act of 2008 formalised the need for improved governance around the use of antimicrobials to help reduce the incidence of healthcare associated infections such as Clostridium difficile and Methicillin Resistant Staphylococcal Aureus (MRSA).

This policy is designed to be used by all staff who are involved in the prescribing, administration, supply or monitoring of antimicrobials. It is intended to help ensure the safe and appropriate use of these medicines through provision of a written framework that covers strategic and practical policy statements, supported by an effective audit programme.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:

Ensure Department of Health and Social Care national best practice for the use of antimicrobials is adhered within the Trust. This includes implementation of UK five year antimicrobial resistance action plan 2019-2024, and  year vision to contain and control AMR by
The scope of this policy relates to any patient of any age treated with antimicrobials by the Trust.
Definitions

table_items.text: Medication capable of causing the evacuation of parasitic intestinal worms.

A therapeutic agent (typically a medicine) used to kill or reduce the number of microbes. This will include Antibacterials, Antivirals, Antifungals, Antiprotozoals (& Anthelmintic) i.e. any therapeutic agent in BNF Chapter 5. On a daily basis, antibacterials provide the main group.

Co-ordinated interventions designed to improve and measure the appropriate use of antimicrobials by promoting the selection of the optimal antimicrobial drug regimen, dose, duration of therapy, and route of administration.
Medication capable of treating infections caused by protozoa (amoebae, flagellates, ciliates and sporozoa).

‘Commissioning for Quality and Innovation' This system was introduced in 2009 to make a proportion of healthcare providers' income conditional on demonstrating improvements in quality and innovation in specified areas of patient care. The CQUIN scheme is intended to deliver clinical quality improvements and drive transformational change. For the purpose of this policy, this relates to antimicrobial targets and indicators within the current CQUIN scheme that apply to the Trust.
The DDD is the assumed average maintenance dose per day for a drug used for its main indication in adults.
Department for Health and Social Care (Formerly Department of Health).

Extended-Spectrum Beta-Lactamases (ESBLs) are enzymes that can be produced by bacteria making them resistant to most antibacterials, especially the penicillins and the cephalosporins. They are often found in urinary tract infections.

Microbes are living organisms that multiply frequently and spread rapidly. They include bacteria (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus, which causes some staph infections), viruses (e.g., influenza, which causes the flu), fungi (e.g., Candida albicans, which causes some yeast infections), and parasites (e.g., Plasmodium falciparum, which causes malaria). Some microbes cause disease, and others exist in the body without causing harm and may actually be beneficial.
Antimicrobials that are on the Trust formulary but require
microbiologist or antimicrobial pharmacist authorisation before pharmacy may supply.
Information collected from already treated patients relating to the use of antibiotics in terms of DDD.

Therapeutic Drug Monitoring is the assessment of treatment effectiveness through the collection and analysis of drug blood levels. This is undertaken for drugs where the toxic and therapeutic levels are close e.g. Gentamicin.

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
MSE Patient Safety & Quality Group
Receiving exception reports and taking action in response to issues raised from Medicines Assurance Group and/or department of pharmacy.
MSE Medicines Assurance Group
Ensuring the effective implementation, use and timely review of this policy;
Ensuring that monitoring arrangements are appropriately performed by the Site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Groups (MOSG);
Ensuring addition of any new antimicrobials onto the formulary is controlled and formally approved (and removal from the formulary of any antimicrobials no longer Trust approved);
Where necessary, escalating concerns to the Chief Nurse or Site Director of Nursing or Medical Director as appropriate;
Exception reporting to the MSE Patient Safety & Quality Group on developments, concerns and progress concerning antimicrobial use.
Site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Group (MOSG)
Monitoring this policy through incident reports;
Reporting antimicrobial incidents to the site Antimicrobial Stewardship Group, as requested;
Escalating issues to site divisional governance groups and MAG as appropriate.
Site Infection Prevention and Control Committee (or equivalent)
Receiving quarterly AMS reports and taking action as necessary.
Site Antimicrobial Stewardship (AMS) Group (or equivalent)
Reporting directly to the site Director of Infection Prevention & Control;
Undertaking an annual review of evidence based local antimicrobial policies (including treatment of common infections, therapeutic drug monitoring guidance and surgical prophylaxis);
Undertaking a biennial review of guidelines that relate to the management of infections with antimicrobials;
Ensuring AMR CQUIN is implemented within the Trust;
Ensure antimicrobial prescribing audits are carried out at least once every quarter, and actions to address non-adherence to the guidelines are identified.
Providing an annual report to IPC to include CQUIN performance, AMS activities, and an assessment against the Acute Hospital Antimicrobial Stewardship Tool (NICE 2015) with any resulting action plan;

Engage in horizon scanning of new antimicrobials, monitor and evaluate the suitability of formulary requests for new antimicrobials in the Trust; Reviewing the restricted antimicrobials list annually;
Ensuring the implementation and review of the antimicrobial training strategy;
Ensuring regular auditing of the guidelines, antimicrobial stewardship practice and quality assurance measures (i.e. the content of this policy);
Identifying actions to address non-adherence with local guidelines & general antimicrobial stewardship issues;
Formally reporting a regular review of the organisation's retrospective antibiotic consumption data (including broad spectrum antibiotic use e.g. cephalosporins, quinolones and carbapenems);
Ensure prescribers have access to timely microbiology diagnosis, susceptibility testing and reporting of results, preferably within 24-72hours;
Ensure all antimicrobial prescribers receive induction and training on prudent antimicrobial use.
Chief Executive

As the Trust's accountable officer has overall responsibility for ensuring the Trust has robust, complete and up to date documents in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.
Chief Medical Officer
Ensuring there is policy compliance through liaising with the Site Medical Directors;
Ensuring sufficient resources are in place to implement this policy;
Ensuring any escalated antimicrobial issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Site Medical Directors
Ensuring that there is policy compliance on site by all professions they oversee;
Ensuring any escalated antimicrobial issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Divisional Medical/Clinical Directors
Ensuring prescribers are implementing and monitoring antimicrobial management in their areas;
Ensuring areas under their responsibility are appropriately monitored and supported following audit to ensure sustained improvement is achieved.
Chief Nursing Officer
Ensuring that there is policy compliance and liaising with the Site Pharmacy, Head of Department & MSE Lead Antimicrobial Pharmacist that antimicrobial stewardship activities are run effectively;
Ensuring sufficient resources are in place to implement this policy;
Ensuring any escalated antimicrobial issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Site Director of Nursing
Ensuring that there is policy compliance on site by all professions they oversee and that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring any escalated antimicrobial issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately;
Ensuring sufficient resources are in place to implement this policy;
Ensuring production of appropriate reports to the Trust Board.
Site Director of Infection Prevention & Control (DIPC)
Ensuring antimicrobial stewardship is effectively implemented within the Trust;
Ensuring the Infection & Prevention Control Committee effectively manage any concerns raised relating to the use of antimicrobials;
Providing the trust board with an annual report regarding Antimicrobial Stewardship;
Ensuring antimicrobial guidelines are informed by local microbiological sensitivity patterns;
Ensuring the microbiology laboratory selectively report sensitivities in line with current local guidelines / formulary choices;
Ensuring multidisciplinary antimicrobial ward rounds occur at least weekly;
Ensuring advice for prescribers is available from consultant microbiologists 24/7;
Ensuring any repeated cases of non-adherence to policy / guidelines are
considered for formal investigation (especially where adverse patient outcomes have occurred);
Ensuring antimicrobial audit programme is undertaken and reviewed annually.
Chief Pharmacist
Setting the overall framework and policy standards for antimicrobials across the organisation, in line with regulatory and best practice guidance;
Ensuring a monitoring process exists and functions for policy standard.
The Chief Pharmacist delegates this responsibility to the site pharmacy heads of department and site clinical lead pharmacists for delivery.
Site Pharmacy Head of Department
Ensuring there is sufficient antimicrobial pharmacist support at the site that is dedicated for AMS activities. This responsibility may be delegated to the site clinical lead pharmacist.
Site Clinical Lead Pharmacist
Ensuring the site lead antimicrobial pharmacist is able to spend majority of their time on antimicrobial related activities (minimum 0.6wte);
Ensuring the antimicrobial pharmacist is supported in continuing education of infection management;

Ensuring any requests for increased pharmacist presence on wards / ward rounds to support improving adherence to antimicrobials are formally acknowledged and actions communicated to the MSE lead antimicrobial pharmacist.
MSE Principal Pharmacist- MSE Antimicrobial Stewardship Lead

Manage and develop the roles of all antimicrobial pharmacists across the MSE Trust to meet the needs of the present and future AMS activities, and promote prudent antimicrobial prescribing without compromising patient's safety;

Develop, facilitate and implement an antimicrobial stewardship strategy for MSE Trust in conjunction with the site antimicrobial pharmacist leads, antimicrobial stewardship groups, heads of pharmacy department and the CCG;

Facilitate, implement and strategize action plan to achieve any antimicrobial related Public Health England (PHE) initiated CQUIN, and key performance indicators (KPIs) targets across the MSE hospitals;
Submit quarterly CQUIN and KPI reports to the relevant governmental bodies;
Develop yearly AMS plan for the site lead antimicrobial pharmacists and monitor execution of the plan;

Ensure prescribing and dispensing of antimicrobials is undertaken to reflect MSE and CCG antimicrobial formulary and to participate in the regular review of drugs used to treat infections; following local, regional and national recommendations;
Collate antimicrobial stewardship activity reports across the hospitals and submit to both MSE IPC and MAG quarterly;
Ensure document control exists for all antimicrobial guidelines;
Ensure only current antimicrobial guidelines are available electronically via the intranet;
Act as a non-medical prescriber within own competences and role;

Provide specialist information and advice within remit, on all aspects of antimicrobials for treating infections to doctors, nurses, other healthcare professionals within MSE Trust and areas supplied under service level agreements;
Actively participate in clinical management team meetings, as needed, to report on AMS activities and clinical governance issues concerning antimicrobial use in MSE Trust.
Site Antimicrobial Pharmacist
Act as the site lead for facilitating antimicrobial stewardship activities;
Ensuring antimicrobial guidelines provide guidance on prescribing in line with NICE recommendations;
Ensuring IV to Oral Switch Guidelines are current, published and enforced;
Ensuring cost effective prescribing of antimicrobials, and provide specialist information and advice for medical, nursing and pharmacy staff at site;
Ensuring execution of action plan to achieve CQUIN, KPIs and audit targets
Ensuring they attend antimicrobial ward rounds regularly, and providing expert prescribing advice and contributing to MDT;
Ensuring implementation of the audit programme based on PHE antimicrobial prescribing principle of ‘ Start Smart, then Focus';
Ensuring each clinical division and directorate within, is audited as scheduled and provided with feedback on performance;
Ensuring they monitor and report antibiotic consumption (using Daily Defined Doses) including AMS activity report to site IPCC, AMS group and MSE lead antimicrobial pharmacist on a quarterly basis;
Investigating all omitted / delayed (> 1hour) first doses of antimicrobials and
reporting to the AMS Group;
Proactive in risk management, ensuring all antimicrobial-related clinical incidents are reported and appropriate action is taken in conjunction with the site MOSG and clinical lead;
Providing a quarterly feedback to clinical divisions, and directorates within, and action plans agreed (with updates at subsequent meetings);
Providing a quarterly CQUIN and KPI reports to the site AMS group and the MSE Principal Antimicrobial Pharmacist;
Facilitating education and training of doctors, Pharmacy staff and nurses within their sites, on relevant aspects of AMS and AMR.
Prescribers
Ensuring allergy status is completed prior to prescribing;
Ensuring cases are assessed for previous antimicrobial therapy and previous infections with multi-resistant organisms before prescribing;
Ensuring nil by mouth status is regularly assessed and documented to facilitate oral administration of antimicrobials where clinically indicated;

Ensuring all first doses of IV antimicrobials are prescribed as stat doses (including required time of administration) and communicating directly with the nurse/midwife looking after that patient, at that time;
Assisting with achieving current elements of CQUIN (see monitoring compliance section) and Trust KPIs;
Incident reporting any policy breaches in accordance with Trust policies MSEPO- 19014 and MSEPO-20206;
Adhering to antimicrobial policies and guidelines including the Department of Health ‘Start Smart then Focus' principle of antimicrobial prescribing.
Registered Nursing staff
Assisting with adherence to antimicrobial policies and guidelines on wards;
Assisting in ensuring every antimicrobial prescription has a stop or review date;
Ensuring allergy status is completed prior to administering;
Ensuring nil by mouth status is regularly assessed and documented to facilitate oral administration of antimicrobials where clinically indicated;
Ensuring injectable antimicrobials are appropriately prioritised on the drug administration round to ensure minimal delay to administration;

Ensure the medicine omitted code for ‘not available' is never used for any first dose antimicrobial and not more than once for any subsequent doses. They must ensure appropriate action is always taken to ensure a dose is obtained as soon as possible in accordance with the Trust Administration of Medicines Policy, or equivalent;
Incident reporting any policy breaches in accordance with Trust policies MSEPO- 19014 and MSEPO-20206.
Registered Pharmacist and Pharmacy Technician
Champion AMS within their clinical areas;
Assisting with antimicrobial audits;
Assisting with adherence to antimicrobial policies and guidelines on wards and through education / training;
Ensuring allergy status is completed prior to dispensing (with minimal delay)

Ensuring all wards have clear information on current antimicrobial stock lists, where to check the list, how to order antimicrobials, and how to acquire non-stock and stock antimicrobials in a timely fashion;
Ensuring any requests for antimicrobials are appropriately managed to avoid any missed doses or delays (especially first doses);
Highlighting non formulary requests or non-approved use of restricted antimicrobial use to the site Antimicrobial Pharmacist (or Consultant Microbiologist in their absence);
Incident reporting any policy breaches in accordance with Trust policies MSEPO-19014 and MSEPO-20206.
Site Antimicrobial Stewardship Core Group
To ensure a multidisciplinary approach, improve engagement across the organisation and based on NICE recommendations this group must contain as a minimum:
Consultant clinical microbiologist or infectious diseases specialist;
Antimicrobial pharmacist/infectious diseases pharmacist;
A physician;
A surgeon;
A senior member of the pharmacy management team;
A senior nurse.

A ward-focused antimicrobial team must function in addition to the stewardship group. This team containing the antimicrobial pharmacist and consultant microbiologist/infectious diseases specialist reports to Antimicrobial Stewardship Group and are responsible for reviewing prescriptions at ward level on multi- disciplinary antimicrobial stewardship ward rounds.
Antimicrobial Prescribing Guidelines

The Antimicrobial Stewardship Group is responsible for all antimicrobial guidelines within the Trust. Whilst each specialty must be consulted on any developments or indeed develop local guidelines for their own infections, they must be approved by this group prior to ratification by the Medicines Assurance Group (MAG).

Guidelines must be evidence-based, relevant to the local healthcare setting and take into account local antibiotic resistance patterns. They should cover treatment of common infections, TDM, surgical prophylaxis and prophylaxis of infection.
Responsibility for guideline implementation resides with the Antimicrobial Stewardship Group.
Goals and essential elements of Antimicrobial prescribing:
To ensure adherence to the principle of antimicrobial prescribing: ‘Start Smart, then Focus':
Start Smart is:
Then Focus is:
*Change includes de-escalation of therapy i.e. to a narrower spectrum agent based on any new clinical information e.g. sensitivities
Minimise unnecessary prescribing of antimicrobials by providing clear clinical case definitions and associated evidence of infection;
Emphasise the need for standard infection prevention and control precautions where appropriate;
For severe or life-threatening infection, emphasise the urgent need to start treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotic agents (particularly where the source of infection is uncertain);

For less severe infection, offer antibiotic agent(s) with an adequate spectrum to cover only the expected pathogens. Broad-spectrum antibiotics are sometimes not as potent in vitro as their narrower-spectrum counterparts against certain pathogens;

Remind prescribers to consider the risk of resistant pathogens such as MRSA or ESBL-producing organisms and offer alternative treatment regimens accordingly or encourage prescribers to seek expert advice;
Highlight the importance of confirming allergy status and offer alternative treatment choices for patients intolerant of recommended antibiotic agents;

Require prescribers to take appropriate specimens for microscopy, culture and sensitivity testing (MC&S) before starting antibiotic treatment wherever possible but not to delay starting treatment in patients who are severely ill;
Recommend intravenous administration only to patients who are severely ill, unable to tolerate oral treatment, or where oral therapy would not provide
adequate coverage or tissue penetration;
Recommend antibiotic doses and remind prescribers to adjust dosing in renal or hepatic impairment;
Require prescribers to review microbiology results daily, and offer empirical de- escalation antibiotic choices;
Offer oral switch choices for intravenous antibiotics;
Provide advice regarding monitoring and follow-up and contingency advice for treatment failure;
Suggest typical treatment course length for intravenous and oral agents;
Require single dose surgical prophylaxis regimens as appropriate;

Patients or their advocate (if the patient lacks capacity as assessed under the Mental Capacity Act 2005) must be informed when they have been prescribed an antimicrobial and the rationale. They must also be informed of the risks and side- effects of the antimicrobial treatment;

Patients discharged on antimicrobials must be informed (or their advocate) of this intention and the reasons. The explanation must also include the course duration, the importance of finishing the course, and possible risks and side- effects (including what to do if they develop when home).
Quality Assurance / Audits

There is an ongoing programme of audit, revision and update monitored by the Antimicrobial Stewardship Group under the supervision of the DIPC. This is to ensure prudent antibiotic prescribing and antimicrobial stewardship. These audits are led by the MSE or site Antimicrobial Pharmacist.
Regular (at least annual) feedback of adherence to prescribing standards must be provided to the Trust Board, prescribers, lead clinicians and microbiologists, nurses, pharmacists and the DIPC.
The audits as a minimum follow the PHE recommended principle of prescribing ‘Start smart-then Focus' (updated 2015) (see appendices 1 and 2).
The Antimicrobial Stewardship Group and the DIPC will review antibiotic consumption trends regularly (at least annually).

Action will be taken by the Antimicrobial Stewardship Group to investigate any non- adherence to local protocols for antibiotic prescribing (based on best practice) or unexpected trends in prescribing. These must be documented in group minutes and any reports.

The DIPC must consider formal investigation of cases of repeated non-compliance (without clinical justification) or inappropriate prescribing, particularly when these result in an adverse patient outcome (e.g. development of an HCAI, prolonged length of stay, etc.). Any decisions not to investigate must be documented by the Antimicrobial Stewardship Group.
It is important that audits include impact on patient outcome to ensure that qualitative or quantitative alterations (changing, reducing, restricting) to
antimicrobial prescribing do not have unintended detrimental effects for example increased time to clinical cure, increased mortality, increased readmission rate.
Education & Training

Antimicrobial prescribers, pharmacists and nurses must receive (or as a minimum complete the online training in 8.2 below) information covering relevant aspects of antimicrobial prescribing, dispensing, administration and counselling on induction. It must cover the existing antimicrobial guidelines and formulary.

All clinical staff involved in antimicrobial use and supply must be competent on AMS and AMR expectations, online resources are available within the online Trust Learning Management System (formerly iLearn).

Nurses play a key role in the safe and timely administration of antibiotics and the collection of specimens that will enable a switch to targeted therapies should be recognised in each organisation. Nurses must be educated in the importance of maintaining therapeutic levels of prescribed medications, avoiding missed or delayed doses of antimicrobials and ensuring that all diagnostic tests are promptly carried out. Nurses also have a role to play in questioning and highlighting the duration of therapies and prescription of medications where these do not meet with established organisational guidelines.

data.text: Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by Medicines Assurance Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local medication documents. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform all prescribers, nursing and pharmacy of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

data.text: Appendix 2 - Components of Best Practice for Antibiotic Prescribing (Peri-operative prophylaxis)

table_items.text: Indication should comply with NICE NG125: Prevention and treatment of surgical site infection or other evidence based recommendations i.e. prophylaxis ‘recommended' or ‘should be considered' for a procedure. Antibiotic prophylaxis is usually only recommended for clean-contaminated, contaminated or dirty procedures, in accordance with local guidelines.
For certain clean procedures, evidence suggests a lack of benefit of antibiotics. However, prophylaxis is required for clean surgery involving the placement of a prosthesis or implant
Annual audit of local surgical prophylaxis practice

Prescribe prophylaxis with appropriate agents according to local guidelines. Use narrow spectrum agent(s) when possible. Avoid cephalosporins, clindamycin, and quinolones whenever possible. Use appropriate alternatives for patients with penicillin/ beta-lactam allergy
Ensure adequate coverage of expected pathogens according to surgical site.
Annual audit of local surgical prophylaxis practice
Administer antibiotics within 60-minutes prior to incision (or tourniquet) or according to local guidelines
Lowest surgical site infection rates associated with pre-incision administration.
Annual audit of local surgical prophylaxis practice
Single dose is indicated for majority of procedures. Reason for antibiotic administration beyond one dose should be documented, and comply with criteria below:
Antibiotics often short half-life or haemodilution effect with replacement fluid or blood products.
Annual audit of local surgical prophylaxis practice

Significant intra-operative blood loss - >1.5 litre (re-dose following fluid replacement). Prolonged procedures (> 6 hours) or where there is significant blood loss may require an additional dose of prophylactic antibiotic – organisations should develop local recommendations for individual patients/procedures , taking into consideration a repeat dose of antibiotic prophylaxis when the operation is longer than the half-life of the antibiotic given. Primary arthroplasty (Single dose is preferable but up to 24 hours prophylaxis acceptable). For certain procedures up to 24 hours of prophylaxis may be warranted and for open heart surgery up to 48 hours

Decolonisation therapy is recommended prior to surgery and antibiotic prophylaxis should include cover for MRSA. Glycopeptides or co- trimoxazole are suitable agents. Gentamicin may also be considered if local resistance rates are low
Integrate into current Saving Lives audits* for surgery or MRSA decolonisation audits
